questions.text: A 28-year-old woman, G1P1, delivered a healthy baby girl via normal vaginal delivery. She is now 2 weeks postpartum and presents for a follow-up visit. On examination, her uterus is not palpable per abdomen. What best describes the normal puerperium duration and uterine involution weight in this patient?

choices.text: Puerperium is until 6 weeks postpartum; uterine weight - 300 grams
Puerperium is until 8 weeks postpartum; uterine weight - 500 grams
Puerperium is until 9 weeks postpartum; uterine weight - 1000 grams
Puerperium is until 6 weeks postpartum; uterine weight - 100 grams

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Puerperium is until 6 weeks postpartum; uterine weight - 300 grams

 

Explanation:

  • Puerperium defines the time following delivery during which pregnancy-induced maternal anatomical and physiological changes return to the nonpregnant state.
  • Puerperium begins as soon as the placenta is expelled and is considered to last between 4 and 6 weeks.

 

Involution of uterus in puerperium :

Duration

Weight of uterus

Uterus palpable

Immediately after delivery

1000gm (Option C)

Just below the umbilicus

*for 1st 24 hours no change in fundal height. Thereafter, FH decreases @ about 1.25 cm/day.

Fundal height approx. 1 finger breath below the umbilicus on the 2nd postpartum day.

1 week after delivery

500gm (Option B)

Midway between the umbilicus and symphysis pubis

2 weeks after delivery

300gm (Option A)

Not palpable (becomes pelvic organ)

4 weeks after delivery

100gm (Option D)

Involutes completely

questions.text: A 30-year-old female who delivered a healthy term baby one week ago is now presenting to the OBG clinic with complaints of fishy-smelling pale brownish vaginal discharge. What is the nature of this discharge?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Lochia Serosa

Explanation:

Lochia Serosa is usually seen from the 5th to the 9th day of puerperium, the color of discharge is yellowish, pink, or pale brownish

  • Lochia is the vaginal discharge seen in early puerperium due to the sloughing of decidual tissue. It has an offensive fishy smell and may last up to 35 days.
  • Depending upon the variation of the colour, the types of Lochia are:

Type of Lochia

Timing

Composition

Lochia Rubra -red

(Option A)

Seen in 1-4 days
  • Blood
  • Shreds of fetal membranes and decidua
  • Vernix caseosa
  • Lanugo and meconium.

Lochia Serosa-yellowish or

pink or pale brownish

(Option B)

5-9 days
  • Less RBC but more leukocytes
  • Wound exudate
  • Mucus from the cervix
  • Microorganisms (anaerobic streptococci and staphylococci)

Lochia Alba-pale white

(Option C)

10-15 days
  • Decidual cells
  • Leukocytes
  • Mucus
  • Cholesterin crystals, fatty and granular epithelial cells
  • Microorganisms.

Leukorrhea (Option D): Profuse white discharge might be seen in vaginitis, cervicitis, or subinvolution

questions.text: During puerperium the female reproductive tract undergoes involution, changes to revert to the non-pregnant state. All of the following statements accurately reflect these changes except?

choices.text: Cervix thickens & endocervical canal reforms by the end of 1st week.
Total number of myocytes declines markedly.
Complete involution of placental site takes up to 6 weeks.
Rugae starts to reform by 2nd to 3rd week.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Total number of myocytes declines markedly.

Explanation:

  • Involution of the uterus involves a decrease in uterine size and weight. During myometrial involution, the number of myocytes remains relatively constant, but their size reduces significantly. After each delivery, the uterus tends to remain slightly larger than before.
  • The superficial decidual layer becomes necrotic and is shed through lochia, while the basal layer regenerates the new endometrium. Endometrial regeneration is rapid—by about one week, the surface is epithelialized, and full restoration is typically seen from the 16th day.
  • However, complete involution and extrusion of the placental site takes up to 6 weeks (Option C).

Changes seen postpartum:

Cervix
  • The cervical opening contracts slowly & for a few days immediately after labor, it readily admits two fingers.
  • By the end of 1st week, this opening narrows, the cervix thickens and the endocervical canal reforms. (Option A)
  • The external os does not completely resume its pre-gravid appearance (recall : multiparous os - transverse slit like)

Vagina
  • Rarely regains the nulliparous dimensions.
  • Rugae starts to reappear by the 3rd week. (Option D)
  • Vaginal epithelium starts to grow by 4 - 6 weeks. This timing is usually coincidental with resumed ovarian estrogen production.
  • Remnants of hymen scar to form the myrtiform caruncles.

questions.text: A 32-year-old G2P1 woman presents on postoperative day 4 following a cesarean section delivery done due to prolonged labor. She complains of increasing lower abdominal pain, foul-smelling vaginal discharge, and fever. On examination, her abdomen is tender over the uterine incision site, and she has mild tachycardia. On investigation, her WBC count was 24,500. What is the gold -standard antibiotic regimen choice for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Clindamycin + Gentamicin

Explanation:

The woman is suffering from postpartum uterine infection (puerperal sepsis). Initial therapy is empirical & early initiation of broad-spectrum antibiotics is the mainstay of treatment. For infections following vaginal delivery, majority of women respond to regimen such as ampicillin plus gentamicin. In contrast, anaerobic coverage is included for infections following cesarean delivery. 

Antimicrobial regimens for pelvic infections following cesarean delivery :

  • Clindamycin + Gentamicin : "Gold standard" regimen, Plus Ampicillin added to the regimen with sepsis or suspected enterococcal infection.
  • Clindamycin + Aztreonam (Gentamicin substitute for renal insufficiency)
  • Ampicillin+Gentamicin (Vaginal delivery)
  • Ampicillin + Gentamicin + Metronidazole (for anaerobic coverage)
  • Extended spectrum cephalosporins 
  • Carbapenems

Puerperal sepsis:

Postpartum uterine infection has been called endometritis, endomyometritis, and endoparametritis. Following vaginal delivery, infection involves the myometrium and parametrial tissues and not just the decidua alone. Infection after cesarean section, is essentially a surgical site infection involving the incised myometrium. Thus, overall the term, metritis with pelvic cellulitis.

Clinical Features:

Signs:

Investigations:

Treatment:
  • Fever
  • Pain abdomen
  • Dirty, foul-smelling discharge
  • Lower abdomen tenderness
  • On P/V examination:

- Uterine and Adnexal tenderness

 
  • Leukocytosis
  • Raised ESR & CRP
  • Broad-spectrum antibiotics are the mainstay of treatment. 
  • For moderate to severe infections (particularly following post cesarean cases) intravenous treatment is indicated.

questions.text: A 30-year-old postnatal mother comes with bleeding PV and lower abdominal cramps, 3 weeks postpartum. USG shows an enlarged uterus and tubular hypoechoic areas in the myometrium. The mother is stable. On bimanual examination, the uterus is larger and softer than normal. She is diagnosed with uterine subinvolution. What is the most common cause of the given diagnosis in her case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Incompletely remodeled spiral arteries.

Explanation:

Incompletely remodeled spiral arteries is the cause here since there are no evidences for a polyp (Option A), retained placental fragments (Option B), or endometritis (Option D).

Inadequate conversion of spiral arteries into remodeled utero-placental arteries can cause subinvolution. These vessels are filled with thromboses & lack an endothelial lining. On USG, the uterus is characteristically enlarged with tubular hypo-echoic areas in the myometrium, that reflect neo-vasculariation & dilated vessels.

Subinvolution

Definition

The uterus fails to return to its normal size after delivery.

Pathogenesis
  • Retained Placental Fragments
  • Incompletely Remodeled Spiral Arteries
  • Infection (endometritis)

Clinical features

Prolonged Lochia.

Irregular/Excessive Uterine Bleeding.

Investigations

Bimanual Examination: The Uterus is larger and softer than normal.

HPE: Perivascular Trophoblasts are seen in Vessel walls - Aberrant Interaction between uterine and trophoblast cells

USG Pelvis: Uterine subinvolution is characterised by an enlarged uterus with Tubular Hypoechoic areas in the Myometrium. These tubular areas reflect neovascularization and dilated uterine vessels.

In contrast, characteristic findings of retained products include a thickened endometrium or endometrial mass & vascularity within the mass.

 

Treatment
  • Uterotonics.
  • Methergine (Methylergonovine) 0.2mg orally every 4 hrs for 24-48hrs.
  • IM dose of Methergine  + oxytocin infusion can be used for initial management of brisk bleeding.
  • Antibiotic treatment is given for suspected cases of infection. Empirical therapy with Azithromycin, Amoxicillin-Clavulanate or Doxycycline is usually effective.
  • Curettage is carried out when appreciable bleeding persists or  recurs after medical management.

questions.text: A 22-year-old mother feels her 6 day old baby seems to be getting only a small amount of thick, yellowish fluid while breastfeeding, despite proper latch and positioning. She gets anxious, and stressed about it. What is the most likely reason for the difficulty with milk ejection during breastfeeding?

choices.text: Increased glucocorticoid levels due to stress
Decreased oxytocin release due to anxiety

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Decreased oxytocin release due to anxiety

Explanation:

In this scenario the thick, yellowish fluid is colostrum and maternal anxiety and stress is interfering with the milk ejection reflex causing difficulty in milk ejection.

  • Milk ejection reflex also known as letting down reflex, is initiated mainly by suckling action of the baby, stimulating the posterior pituitary to secrete oxytocin in a pulsatile fashion which causes contraction of myoepithelial cells in alveoli and milk ducts to express the milk.

Factors promoting let-down reflex

Factors inhibiting let-down reflex

  • Infant cry
  • Frequent feeding
  • Proper positioning and latching

 
  • Pain
  • Breast engorgement
  • Maternal stress, anxiety (Option B), and depression

 


Glucocorticoids (Option A) and prolactin (Option C) are involved in lactogenesis.
 

Progesterone (Option D) inhibits lactogenesis. Also, it does not play a role in milk ejection.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman, two weeks postpartum, is concerned about decreased milk production as her baby shows signs of hunger. On evaluation with blood tests reveal low levels of a certain hormone. Which hormone is most likely to be low?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Prolactin

Explanation:
Prolactin is the single most important galactopoietic hormone.

Hormones and breast milk production:

  • Prolactin levels fall after delivery and the basal levels are low in postpartum period
  • Episodic rise is required for subsequent lactation and maintenance in the postpartum period, which happens during each act of suckling.

Hormones that favor milk production

Hormones that inhibit milk production
  • Prolactin (Option B)
  • Insulin
  • Glucocorticoids
  • Growth hormone
  • Thyroxine
  • Estrogen (Option C)
  • Progesterone (Option D)


Oxytocin  (Option A) is involved primarily in milk ejection, not production.

questions.text: A 28 year-old HIV+ pregnant female who is on ART delivered a male baby, she is being treated for latent TB and also has Hepatitis B infection with low viral load. Immediately after the delivery the baby was given Hepatitis B immunoglobulin. What advice would you give to the mother regarding breastfeeding?

choices.text: She can breastfeed the baby without any restrictions
Breastfeeding should be avoided as the mother is HIV+
Should not breastfeed as the mother is not receiving treatment for Hepatitis B
Breastfeeding should be avoided as the mother has HIV, Latent TB and Hepatitis B infection.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) She can breastfeed the baby without any restrictions

Explanation:
Despite all 3 conditions, baby can be breastfed as HIV is not a contraindication for breastfeeding in India and the mother is also on treatment for latent TB, and the baby has been given Hepatitis B immunoglobulin.

Contraindications of Breastfeeding:

Maternal causes
  1. Uncontrolled alcohol and drug abusers
  2. Active or untreated Tb
  3. Active herpes infection with lesion on breast
  4. Undergoing breast cancer treatment
  5. On drugs like cyclophosphamide, cyclosporine,doxorubicin, methotrexate,mycophenolate

Fetal causes

Galactosemia

Prophylaxis for baby

  • HIV- give neviripine to baby
  • Untreated TB- INH prophylaxis to baby
  • Hepatitis B infection-Vaccine +IVIG to baby

questions.text: A 28-year-old breastfeeding mother complains of severe pain, redness, and swelling in her left breast, along with fever and chills for 7 days. The patient was put on antibiotics for mastitis but there is no improvement, she also has history of recurrent mastitis. On examination, there is a large fluctuant mass on left side and tenderness is present. What is the next line of management of above conditions?

choices.text: Drain the abscess, continue antibiotics and consider lactation consultation for prevention
Stop breastfeeding, continue oral antibiotics and apply cold compresses
Drain the abscess, start antifungal treatment and wean the baby
Stop antibiotics, switch to IV antifungal treatment and continue breastfeeding

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Drain the abscess, continue antibiotics and consider lactation consultation for prevention

Explanation:

From the given question, severe pain, redness, swelling along with fluctuating mass, and tenderness of left breast indicates breast abscess with mastitis. This is treated by drainage and antibiotics.

Mastitis

Definition

Parenchymal infection of mammary glands

Causative organism

Staph. Aureus (most common), Streptococci 

Risk factors

Difficult nursing, cracked nipples, oral antibiotic therapy

Source of infection

Newborn's throat and nose

Treatment of Mastitis
  • Analgesics
  • Hot fomentation with breast milk expression
  • Dicloxacillin, Erythromycin (in penicillin-resistant cases)

Complications of Mastitis

Breast abscess (Variable destruction of breast tissue by recurrent Mastitis)

Treatment of Breast abscess
  • Abscess is drained under LA by giving radical incision in most dependent part and breaking of loculi by finger exploration.
  • Now the cavity is closed with gauze, which is replaced for every 24 hours till the cavity gets healed.

Stop breastfeeding, continue oral antibiotics and apply cold compresses (Option B): Abscess requires drainage and breastfeeding should continue to resolve the infection

Drain the abscess, start antifungal treatment and wean the baby (Option C): As it is a bacterial abscess antifungal treatment not indicated and breastfeeding shall be continued

Stop antibiotics, switch to IV antifungal treatment and continue breastfeeding  (Option D): Antifungal treatment not indicated.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman, who gave birth 3 months ago, presents with symptoms of anxiety, palpitations, and weight loss. Her thyroid function tests reveal abnormalities. What is the most likely phase of postpartum thyroiditis she is experiencing?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Thyrotoxic phase

Explanation:

Postpartum thyroiditis:

Definition

Postpartum thyroiditis is an inflammation of the thyroid gland that occurs after childbirth, typically within the first year postpartum

Etiology
  • Autoimmune Factors:
    Autoimmune Thyroiditis: Postpartum thyroiditis is often an autoimmune condition, characterized by the presence of thyroid autoantibodies (e.g., anti-thyroid peroxidase (anti-TPO) antibodies).
    Immune Rebound: After childbirth, the immune system rebounds from the immunosuppressed state of pregnancy, which can trigger an autoimmune attack on the thyroid.
  • Genetic Predisposition
  • Hormonal Changes

Clinical manifestations

It has 2 phases which has a clinical progression-

Thyrotoxic phase( 1-4 months) (Option A)

Hypothyroid phase( 4 to 8 months) (Option B)

The hypothyroid phase either leads to euthyroid phase (Option C) or permanent hypothyroidism (Option D).

Investigation

Thyroid Function Tests:

  • TSH: Elevated in the hypothyroid phase, suppressed in the hyperthyroid phase.
  • Free T4: Elevated in the hyperthyroid phase, decreased in the hypothyroid phase.
  • Free T3: May also be elevated in the hyperthyroid phase.

Thyroid Antibodies:

  • Anti-thyroid Peroxidase (Anti-TPO) Antibodies: Often elevated, indicating an autoimmune component.

Treatment:
  1. Hyperthyroid phase- Beta blockers
  2. Hypothyroid phase- Levothyroxine, (25 mcg to 75 mcg)

Regular monitoring and long term follow up of the thyroid profile.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman who had severe postpartum hemorrhage two months ago reports fatigue, inability to breastfeed, and decreased libido. She also has noted significant weight gain and cold intolerance. Which diagnostic test is most likely to confirm the suspected diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) MRI brain

Explanation:

Given the history of severe postpartum hemorrhage and the symptoms, Sheehan's syndrome (postpartum hypopituitarism) is suspected. MRI of the pituitary gland can reveal an empty sella or reduced pituitary size.

Sheehan Syndrome:

 

Definition

Postpartum hypopituitarism caused by ischemic necrosis of the pituitary gland following severe postpartum hemorrhage.

Symptoms
  • Failure to lactate
  • Hypotension
  • Hypoglycemia
  • fatigue
  • amenorrhea
  • Hypothyroidism
  • adrenal insufficiency
  • decreased libido
  • weight gain
  • cold intolerance

Diagnosis
  • Clinical history of severe postpartum hemorrhage.
  • Hormonal evaluation: Low levels of pituitary hormones (prolactin, TSH, ACTH, LH, FSH, growth hormone).
  • MRI: Empty sella or reduced pituitary size.(Option C)

Treatment:

Lifelong hormone replacement therapy (glucocorticoids, levothyroxine, estrogen-progesterone, growth hormone if needed)

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman, G3P3 (gravida 3, para 3), presents at 12 weeks postpartum. She reports persistent low mood, loss of interest in activities, insomnia and social withdrawal. She denies any suicidal thoughts. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial management?

choices.text: Referral to a psychotherapist for cognitive-behavioral therapy
Start with Chlorpromazine and sublingual estradiol
Observation and reassessment after one month

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Referral to a psychotherapist for cognitive-behavioral therapy

Explanation:

The given clinical scenario with persistent low mood, loss of interest in activities, social withdrawal, and denial of suicidal thoughts presenting after 12 weeks points towards Postpartum Depression.The Scenario describes mild to moderate postpartum depression for which psychotherapy is considered initially. If the response doesn't improve then antidepressants are considered.

 

Postpartum Blues

Postpartum Depression

Postpartum Psychosis

Onset

4-5 days after delivery, lasts a few days

Gradual onset over 4-6 months following delivery or abortion

Sudden, typically within 4 days of delivery

Duration

Transient, lasts for a few days

Can persist beyond postpartum period

Can persist beyond postpartum period

Symptoms
  • Depression
  • Anxiety
  • Tearfulness
  • Insomnia
  • Negative feelings
  • Loss of energy and appetite
  • Insomnia
  • Social withdrawal
  • Irritability
  • Suicidal attitude
  • Fear
  • Restlessness
  • Hallucinations
  • Delusions
  • Disorientation
  • Suicidal and infantile impulses

Treatment
  • Reassurance
  • psychological support
  • CBT
  • SSRIs, estrogen Patch later.
  • Urgent psychiatric consultation, hospitalization.
  • Chlorpromazine, sublingual estradiol, lithium, ECT (if necessary)

Prognosis

Good

Good with treatment

High risk of recurrence

Breastfeeding

Generally safe

Safe with SSRIs

Contraindicated with some medications (Lithium)

SSRIs (Option B) are only considered initially in severe postpartum depression and in PPD that are not responsive to CBT.

Start with Chlorpromazine and sublingual estradiol (Option C): It is used in the management of Postpartum Psychosis and has no role in Postpartum Depression.

Observation and reassessment after one month (Option D): Delaying treatment for one month may worsen symptoms and affect the well-being of both the mother and baby. Prompt intervention is important to prevent complications associated with untreated PPD.
